TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit WebPartCollection extends System.Collections.ReadOnlyCollectionBase
Public NotInheritable Class WebPartCollection Inherits ReadOnlyCollectionBase

Docs.summary: Contains a collection of controls used to track and manage related groups of controls. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> class is a read-only collection of controls, typically used by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZoneBase> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> controls to manage sets of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls.
A <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> control uses a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object to keep a list of all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on a page, whereas a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZoneBase> control uses a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object to track the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls that it contains.
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> collection contains both <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls and other server controls (such as user controls, custom controls, and ASP.NET controls) that are placed in <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZoneBase> zones and used as part of Web Parts applications. So, for example, if you have a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZone> zone in a page, and within it you declare a custom <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control and the ASP.NET <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Calendar> control, both controls will be in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> collection referenced by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.WebParts%2A> property.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object exists so that the Web Parts control set can work with strongly typed collections. Similarly, if you want to perform mass operations on a set of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls, you can get a reference to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.WebParts%2A> property. For example, you might want to loop through all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on a page and change their appearance in some way. Even though the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object is read-only, you can make programmatic changes to the properties of the underlying controls referenced in the collection.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object on a Web Parts page. This example has three parts:
- The code for the page in a partial class.
- The Web page that contains the controls.
- A description of how the example works in a browser.
The first part of the code example contains the code for the page in a partial class. Note that the `Button1_Click` method creates a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object that consists of all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls referenced in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.WebParts%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property, which includes all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on the page. The method iterates through all the controls, and toggles each control's <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.ChromeState%2A> property, which determines whether that control is normal or minimized.
[!code-csharp[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/CS/webpartcollection.cs#1)] [!code-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/VB/webpartcollection.vb#1)]
The second part of the code example is the Web page that contains the controls. Notice that the controls declared in `WebPartZone1` are standard ASP.NET server controls, but because they are wrapped as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> controls at run time, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> class inherits from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> class, the controls are automatically treated as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls at run time and therefore are included in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object.
[!code-aspx-csharp[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/CS/webpartcollectioncs.aspx#2)] [!code-aspx-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/VB/webpartcollectionvb.aspx#2)]
After you load the page in a browser and click the **Toggle ChromeState** button, the code in the partial class loops through the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object and alternately minimizes the controls or returns them to normal. Or, if you repeatedly click the **Toggle BulletedList1 Title** button, the title of the uppermost control is changed to alternate values.

Docs.summary: Initializes an empty new instance of the class.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.%23ctor%2A> constructor initializes an empty instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> class. The object itself is read-only and has no method to add individual <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls to it; therefore, you will have little occasion to use this constructor.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class System.Collections.ICollection webParts) cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of a object by passing in an collection of controls.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.%23ctor%2A> constructor initializes an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> class by passing in a collection of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls.
Although a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object is read-only and there is no method for adding individual controls to it, you can create your own <xref:System.Collections.ICollection> collection of controls, and pass that to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.%23ctor%2A> constructor. This enables you to create custom collections and perform bulk operations on them. You can also access the underlying controls in the collection and change their property values programmatically.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.%23ctor%2A> constructor on a Web Parts page. This example has three parts:
- The code for the page in a partial class.
- The Web page that contains the controls.
- A description of how the example works in a browser.
The first part of the code example contains the code for the page in a partial class. Note that the `Button1_Click` method creates a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object that consists of all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls referenced in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.WebParts%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property, which includes all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on the page. The method iterates through all the controls, and toggles each control's <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.ChromeState%2A> property, which determines whether that control is normal or minimized.
[!code-csharp[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/CS/webpartcollection.cs#1)] [!code-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/VB/webpartcollection.vb#1)]
The second part of the code example is the Web page that contains the controls. Notice that the controls declared in `WebPartZone1` are standard ASP.NET server controls, but because they are wrapped as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> controls at run time, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> class inherits from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> class, the controls are automatically treated as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls at run time and therefore are included in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object.
[!code-aspx-csharp[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/CS/webpartcollectioncs.aspx#2)] [!code-aspx-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/VB/webpartcollectionvb.aspx#2)]
After you load the page in a browser, click the **Toggle ChromeState** button, and notice that the code in the partial class loops through the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object and alternately minimizes the controls or returns them to normal. Or, if you repeatedly click the **Toggle BulletedList1 Title** button, the title of the uppermost control is changed to alternate values.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.Contains%2A> method enables you to check a particular <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> object and determine whether it is part of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object.

Public Sub CopyTo (array As WebPart(), index As Integer)

Docs.param: An array of objects to contain the copied collection.
The starting point in the array at which to place the collection contents.
Docs.summary: Copies the collection to an array of objects.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.CopyTo%2A> method is useful when you want to assemble a custom array that can contain the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object, a subset of those controls, or a superset of those controls.

Docs.param: A that is a member of the collection.
Docs.summary: Returns the position of a particular member of the collection.
Docs.returns: An integer that indicates the position of a particular object in the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.IndexOf%2A> method is useful if you have multiple <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on a Web Parts page, and you need to know the ordinal position of one control relative to the others.

Docs.summary: Returns a specific member of the collection according to its position or a unique identifier.

MemberSignature.Value: Default Public ReadOnly Property Item(index As Integer) As WebPart

Docs.param: The index of a particular control in a collection.
Docs.summary: Returns a member of the collection based on its position in the collection.
Docs.value: A at the specified index in the collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.Item%2A> indexer allows you to access the underlying <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object by index, and change their property values or call methods.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.Item%2A> indexer on a Web Parts page. This example has three parts:
- The code for the page in a partial class.
- The Web page that contains the controls.
- A description of how the example works in a browser.
The first part of the code example contains the code for the page in a partial class. Note that the `Button2_Click` method creates an empty <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object, then assigns to it the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls from the `WebPartZone1.WebParts` property. The method accesses the first control in the collection by using its index, and toggles its <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.Title%2A> property value.
[!code-csharp[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/CS/webpartcollection.cs#1)] [!code-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/VB/webpartcollection.vb#1)]
The second part of the code example is the Web page that contains the controls. Notice that the controls declared in `WebPartZone1` are standard ASP.NET server controls, but because they are wrapped as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> controls at run time, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> class inherits from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> class, the controls can be treated as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls at run time and made part of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object.
[!code-aspx-csharp[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/CS/webpartcollectioncs.aspx#2)] [!code-aspx-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview/VB/webpartcollectionvb.aspx#2)]
After you load the page in a browser, click the **Toggle BulletedList1 Title** button, and notice that the code toggles the title of the control between the two available title choices.

MemberSignature.Value: Default Public ReadOnly Property Item(id As String) As WebPart

Docs.param: The unique identifier for a particular control in a collection.
Docs.summary: Returns a member of the collection based on a unique string identifier.
Docs.value: The first in the collection whose ID equals the value of .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.Item%2A> indexer enables you to access a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object according to a unique identifier.
> [!NOTE] > The Web Parts control set performs case-insensitive matching on this property, so case sensitivity is not part of a unique `id` value.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection.Item%2A> property also works to identify members of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object in some specialized cases. In the case of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> controls, the indexer is able to match the identifier for the underlying child control wrapped by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> control. In the case of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart> controls, the indexer matches the identifier for the control based on a case-insensitive comparison of the `id` parameter and either the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart.OriginalID%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart.GenericWebPartID%2A> property values.
